Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Interface Engineering for Low-Temperature Process and Stable Organometal Perovskite Solar Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Photovoltaic (PV) technology is a promising method to convert sustainable solar energy into electricity. In order to further lower the cost of solar electricity, increasing efficiency of solar cells, and therefore solar cell modules, becomes more critical because the same power target can be reached with the installation of fewer modules. Recently, organometal halide perovskites have attracted considerable attention as promising PV materials because of the rapid increase in single-junction record efficiencies to exceed 20%, their simple device structures, and the possibility for roll-to-roll low-cost manufacturing on flexible substrates. However, achieving high performance via a low-temperature manufacture process and long-term solar cell stability is still challenging for solar cells based on organometal halide perovskites. This research project seeks to gain fundamental knowledge supporting the discovery of new solar cell interface materials that will have greater stability towards moisture and air while retaining high efficiency. The project is also providing research opportunities for freshmen from the Clean Energy Alliances for Learning and Vision for Underrepresented Americans (ALVA) program and leveraging the research results for the outreach program of Introduce A Girl to Photonics Fair. The fundamental knowledge gained from these materials will make significant impacts on the fields of photovoltaics, optoelectronics and new semiconductor materials.

The objective of this research project is to research new hole transport layer (HTL) materials to improve the performance and stability of perovskite solar cells by introducing internal dipoles and by manipulating the morphology of perovskite films. The new HTL materials utilize poly (3, 4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) as a hole transport backbone while different functional group side chains offer to form dipole that could modify the band energy alignment. By modifying the band energy alignment of the HTL structure and the morphology of the perovskite layers, it is hypothesized that an improvement in charge transport and collection as well as device stability will result. The PEDOT-based HTL materials are being synthesized and the electronic, optical and structural properties of HTL thin films fabricated at low temperatures are being investigated. The new PEDOT-based HTLs are being deployed in planar p-i-n structure perovskite solar cells and the device performance and stability are being tested. Organometal halide perovskites exhibit a broad range of band gap enabling the possibility to make highly efficient single-junction and tandem solar cells. This research project could transform photovoltaic technology and make it possible to commercialize perovskite-based photovoltaic technology with competitively low cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photovoltaic (PV) technology is a promising clean and sustainable source of energy. In order to further lower the levelized cost of solar electricity, increasing efficiency of solar cells, and thus modules, becomes more critical because the same power target can be reached with the installation of fewer modules. Recently, organometal halide perovskites have attracted considerable attention as promising PV materials because of the rapid increase in single-junction record efficiencies to exceed 20%, their simple device structures, and the possibility for roll-to-roll low-cost manufacturing on flexible substrates. However, achieving high performance via low-temperature process and long-term air stability is still challenging for solar cells based on organometal halide perovskites. Here, we propose to utilize low-temperature process for achieving high performance and stable perovskite-based solar cells by developing new poly (3, 4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) with different functional groups as unique hole transport layer (HTL) materials.

Intellectual Merit: In this work, we successfully synthesize monomers of EDOT with different functional groups including EDOT-CH2Cl, EDOT-CH2Br, EDOT-CH2OH and EDOT-CH2N(CH2)2 and characterized the purity of the products. We used oxidative chemical polymerization method in the presence of polyelectrolyte poly(styrene sulfonate) (PSS) to obtain water soluble PEDOT-X:PSS, where X stands for different functional groups. We show that the concentration of oxidant, the molar ratio of oxidant and base to monomer, and the reaction temperature affect the oxidation state and chain length of functionalized PEDOT and the solubility of PEDOT-X:PSS, which influence the electrical conductivity, work function, surface morphology, and chemical structures of PEDOT-X:PSS thin films. We further investigate the post-polymerization treatment, by adding polar solvent such as ethylene glycol in PEDOT-X:PSS solution and by annealing in non-polar solvent (e.g., toluene) environment, on the electrical conductivity, surface morphology and chemical structure of PEDOT-X:PSS thin films. We deploy PEDOT-CH2Cl:PSS and PEDOT-CH2OH:PSS as the HTLs in MAPbI3 perovskite solar cells, evaluate the device performance, and investigate the charge recombination at the HTL/MAPbI3 interface. Superior performance and more stable devices are demonstrated with functionalized PEDOT:PSS HTLs.

Broader Impact: The new HTL materials developed in this project make it possible to fabricate perovskite solar cells at low temperature in a roll-to-roll way, which could transform the photovoltaic technology and commercialize perovskite-based photovoltaic technology with competitively low cost. The results from this project make significant impacts on the fields of photovoltaics, optoelectronics, new semiconductor materials, and bio-electronic materials. Graduate, undergraduate, and community college students received training and participated in this highly interdisciplinary research project, especially students from underrepresented groups such as female. The knowledge gained from this work have been disseminated through the scientific publications and presentations, the new course the PI developed, the Introduce A Girl series outreach program, and the UW Clean Energy Institute outreach program to the local elementary school to help the science project.

 


Last Modified: 09/19/2019
Modified by: Qiuming Yu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Photovoltaic (PV) technology is a promising clean and sustainable source of energy. In order to further lower the levelized cost of solar electricity, increasing efficiency of solar cells, and thus modules, becomes more critical because the same power target can be reached with the installation of fewer modules. Recently, organometal halide perovskites have attracted considerable attention as promising PV materials because of the rapid increase in single-junction record efficiencies to exceed 20%, their simple device structures, and the possibility for roll-to-roll low-cost manufacturing on flexible substrates. However, achieving high performance via low-temperature process and long-term air stability is still challenging for solar cells based on organometal halide perovskites. Here, we propose to utilize low-temperature process for achieving high performance and stable perovskite-based solar cells by developing new poly (3, 4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) with different functional groups as unique hole transport layer (HTL) materials. Intellectual Merit: In this work, we successfully synthesize monomers of EDOT with different functional groups including EDOT-CH2Cl, EDOT-CH2Br, EDOT-CH2OH and EDOT-CH2N(CH2)2 and characterized the purity of the products. We used oxidative chemical polymerization method in the presence of polyelectrolyte poly(styrene sulfonate) (PSS) to obtain water soluble PEDOT-X:PSS, where X stands for different functional groups. We show that the concentration of oxidant, the molar ratio of oxidant and base to monomer, and the reaction temperature affect the oxidation state and chain length of functionalized PEDOT and the solubility of PEDOT-X:PSS, which influence the electrical conductivity, work function, surface morphology, and chemical structures of PEDOT-X:PSS thin films. We further investigate the post-polymerization treatment, by adding polar solvent such as ethylene glycol in PEDOT-X:PSS solution and by annealing in non-polar solvent (e.g., toluene) environment, on the electrical conductivity, surface morphology and chemical structure of PEDOT-X:PSS thin films. We deploy PEDOT-CH2Cl:PSS and PEDOT-CH2OH:PSS as the HTLs in MAPbI3 perovskite solar cells, evaluate the device performance, and investigate the charge recombination at the HTL/MAPbI3 interface. Superior performance and more stable devices are demonstrated with functionalized PEDOT:PSS HTLs. Broader Impact: The new HTL materials developed in this project make it possible to fabricate perovskite solar cells at low temperature in a roll-to-roll way, which could transform the photovoltaic technology and commercialize perovskite-based photovoltaic technology with competitively low cost. The results from this project make significant impacts on the fields of photovoltaics, optoelectronics, new semiconductor materials, and bio-electronic materials. Graduate, undergraduate, and community college students received training and participated in this highly interdisciplinary research project, especially students from underrepresented groups such as female. The knowledge gained from this work have been disseminated through the scientific publications and presentations, the new course the PI developed, the Introduce A Girl series outreach program, and the UW Clean Energy Institute outreach program to the local elementary school to help the science project.
